B. Geoci. Petrobras, Rio de Janeiro, v. 14, n. 2, p. 235-245, maio/nov. 2006 239

mento ?, de valor conhecido, da ordem de 1,42
X 10-11.ano-1, que corresponde a uma meia-vida
de 48,8 Ga no caso do 87Rb.

O método radiométrico Rb-Sr é tradicio-
nalmente aplicado para determinação de idades
absolutas de rochas ígneas, pelo fato das condi-
ções de formação destas serem de alta tempera-
tura. No caso da cristalização de um magma, o
87Sr radiogênico possui considerável mobilidade
e migra entre as fases minerais enquanto a tem-
peratura for superior a 350° C. Como resultado,
ocorre um fenômeno chamado homogeneização
isotópica do Sr, o qual é interrompido pelo resfri-
amento da rocha considerada. Assim, a idade
Rb-Sr estará relacionada a este processo de fe-
chamento do sistema obtido no evento de cris-
talização da rocha.

Uma particularidade que deve ser levada em
consideração reside no fato de que, em qualquer
processo de cristalização a partir de um magma,
existem quantidades de Sr inicial que conferem
àquele sistema uma proporção isotópica ou ra-
zão inicial 87Sr/86Sr. Assim, para rochas cuja razão
inicial 87Sr/86Sr for conhecida ou convencionada,
análises individuais fornecem a idade convencio-
nal da amostra. Alternativamente, se o conheci-
mento das condições de geração do magma não
for preciso, não podem ser arbitradas razões iso-
tópicas iniciais. A idade resultará então da linha
de melhor ajuste entre diversos pontos plotados
num diagrama isocrônico, que possui no eixo X
as razões 87Rb/86Sr e no eixo Y as proporções
87Sr/86Sr das amostras consideradas.

na natureza, não forma minerais próprios. Assim
sendo, sempre é encontrado como impureza nos
minerais potássicos (muscovita, biotita, lepidolita,
ilita e feldspato potássico). Esse comportamento
resulta do fato do raio iônico do Rb (1,48 Å) ser
muito semelhante ao raio do K (cerca de 11%
maior que o do K). O Rb apresenta propriedades
mais alcalinas do que o K, fato este importante
quando da adsorção desses elementos pelos ar-
gilominerais. Ele apresenta dois isótopos de ocor-
rência natural: 85Rb (isótopo estável) e 87Rb (isó-
topo instável).

O estrôncio (Sr) é um elemento químico do
grupo II da tabela periódica que inclui os elemen-
tos alcalinos terrosos: berílio (Be), cálcio (Ca), bá-
rio (Ba) e rádio (Ra). O raio iônico do Sr (1,13 Å)
tem valor próximo do íon Ca (0,99 Å), sendo o
Sr aproximadamente 13% maior que o Ca. Assim
sendo, torna-se possível a substituição do íon Ca
pelo íon Sr em minerais como plagioclásio, apati-
ta e calcita. O elemento Sr pode formar diversos
minerais próprios, dos quais somente a estron-
cianita (SrCO3) e a celestita (SrSO4) são impor-
tantes pela massa que perfazem. O Sr apresenta
quatro isótopos de ocorrência natural: 84Sr, 86Sr e
88Sr – isótopos não radiogênicos – e 87Sr – isóto-
po radiogênico.

O método radiométrico Rb-Sr relaciona-se ao
processo de desintegração radioativa de um isó-
topo pai ou radioativo (Rb de massa 87) que se
transforma em um isótopo filho ou radiogênico
(Sr de massa 87). Esta desintegração radioativa
se processa segundo uma constante de decai-

Idade deposicional da Formação Bananeiras (Bacia de Sergipe-Alagoas) - Silva et al.240

No ambiente sedimentar, caracterizado por
temperaturas mais baixas, o comportamento dos
íons de Rb e Sr é diferenciado. O Rb é mais facil-
mente adsorvido pelos argilominerais, enquanto
o Sr tende a ser liberado da estrutura cristalina
dos minerais para os fluidos intersticiais. Supõe-
se que esta característica favoreça o processo de
homogeneização isotópica do Sr no momento
da deposição dos sedimentos numa determina-
da bacia, condição necessária para a datação ra-
diométrica Rb-Sr (Compston e Pidgeon, 1962;
Faure, 1986; Mizusaki, 1992).

Considerando-se válida a suposição da homo-
geneização isotópica do Sr nos sedimentos, no
momento da deposição, o sucesso de uma data-
ção radiométrica pelo método Rb-Sr em rochas
sedimentares depende – como salientam Mizu-
saki (1992), Mizusaki et al. (1998) e Cordani et
al. (2004) – da seleção de amostras com alto
teor de fração argila, composta por argilomine-
rais expansivos como a esmectita e o interestrati-
ficado ilita-esmectita amostradas segundo as re-
comendações de Thomaz Filho e Lima (1979).

a m o s t r a g e m  e  t é c n i c a s
a n a l í t i c a s     

As amostras estudadas neste trabalho provêm
da seção pré-rifte da Bacia de Sergipe-Alagoas,
estratigraficamente posicionadas na porção infe-
rior da Formação Bananeiras (fig. 4). Foram cole-
tadas 12 amostras em afloramento na rodovia
BR-101, nas proximidades da Vila Bananeiras (SE),

(Latitude: 10º18’52”S e Longitude: 36º53’43”W)
para serem analisadas pelo método radiométrico
Rb-Sr. Os critérios de Thomaz Filho e Lima (1979)
e Mizusaki (1992) foram seguidos, ou seja, amos-
tragem em intervalos regulares, centimétricos,
ausência de carbonatos e de minerais potássicos
tais como micas e feldspatos potássicos. 

Das 12 amostras originais, foram seleciona-
das seis com base nos resultados das análises de
difratometria de raios X (DRX) e nas característi-
cas macroscópicas visuais. Neste caso, foram as
amostras com maior teor semiquantitativo de ar-
gilominerais expansivos bem como ausência de
carbonatos, micas e feldspatos potássicos. Em
seguida, procedeu-se à análise isotópica das seis
amostras que também apresentaram variadas
razões Rb/Sr, conforme sugerido por Mizusaki et
al. (1998). A análise isotópica visou à determi-
nação dos teores em ppm dos elementos Rb e Sr
e das razões 87Sr/86Sr e 87Rb/86Sr. Tais análises
foram realizadas no Centro de Pesquisas Geo-
cronológicas do Instituto de Geociências da Uni-
versidade de São Paulo (USP/IG/CPGeo).

Inicialmente, as amostras foram secas em es-
tufa com temperatura controlada, atingindo no
máximo 70° C, evitando-se assim danos na es-
trutura dos argilominerais, que poderiam prejudi-
car a análise isotópica. Em seguida procedeu-se:

• Determinação semiquantitativa e quantita-
tiva dos teores de Rb e Sr pela técnica da fluo-
rescência de raios X;
• Dissolução total das amostras por digestão
química e separação dos elementos Rb, Sr pe-
la passagem em colunas com resina catiônica
AG-50W-X8 da Bio Rad;

• Análises das razões isotópicas em um espec-
trômetro Micromass VG 354 Multi-collector.
Os elementos, separados nas colunas cati-
ônicas, foram depositados em filamentos
apropriados (simples de Ta para Rb e Sr) com
ácido fosfórico (H3PO4) 0,25N e analisados no
chamado “modo estático”. Foram medidas
100 razões com feixe de íons da ordem de 1 V
e com precisão externa baseada em padrão in-
terno que é medido repetidamente sendo da
ordem de 20 ppm (2 ?). Todas as análises
foram ajustadas baseando-se nos padrões in-
terno e externo NBS-987 (carbonato de es-
trôncio), com média de 0,71028 ± 0,00006.
Durante as separações químicas processadas,
os brancos de Sr foram inferiores a 150 pico-
gramas (pg) enquanto os de Rb foram meno-
res que 750 pg, valores considerados ideais. 
• Construção do diagrama isocrônico com os
resultados isotópicos obtidos para as amos-
tras da Formação Bananeiras por meio do
programa estatístico Isoplot (Ludwig, 2003).

resultados 
As amostras analisadas podem ser macroscopi-

camente caracterizadas como folhelhos de coloração
avermelhada a esverdeada. As análises pela técnica
da difratometria de raios X (na fração fina (FF) <2 µm)
permitiram identificar o predomínio do interestratifi-
cado ilita-esmectita com traços de ilita, esmectita e
caolinita. Os resultados da aplicação da metodolo-

gia Rb-Sr em rocha total encontram-se na tabela 1.
Os valores das amostras de Rb variam entre 86,8 e
102,3 ppm e de Sr entre 187,4 e 564,4 ppm. Os
valores da razão 87Sr/86Sr vão de 0,7133 a 0,7167 e
os da razão 87Rb/86Sr ficam entre 0,383 e 1,422.

As razões isotópicas obtidas para as amostras
FB-02 C40, FB-05 C40, FB-11 C40 e FB-12 C40
da Formação Bananeiras foram plotadas no pro-
grama estatístico Isoplot (Ludwig, 2003), definin-
do uma isócrona que aponta para uma idade da
rocha em 227,1 ± 2,2 Ma (fig. 5). As amostras
FB-01 C40 e FB-09 C40 não foram utilizadas para
o traçado por terem razões muito próximas às
das demais já presentes no diagrama.

A idade isocrônica de 227,1 ± 2,2 Ma (Neo-

triássico) obtida a partir das amostras da Forma-

ção Bananeiras é considerada como representa-

tiva da idade deposicional desta unidade; admi-

te-se que o processo de uniformização isotópica

do Sr foi penecontemporâneo ao processo de se-

dimentação. A ausência de alterações diagené-

ticas significativas da mineralogia original corro-

bora a validação do resultado como idade depo-

sicional. Além disso, o reduzido erro estatístico

(1%) registrado para as amostras analisadas é

compatível com a aplicação do método Rb-Sr em

rochas sedimentares, conforme discutido em Mi-

zusaki (1992). 

A idade absoluta de 227,1 ± 2,2 Ma (Neo-

triássico) agora obtida, em caráter pioneiro, traz

importantes implicações aos esquemas paleo-

geográficos anteriormente estabelecidos. A seção

pré-rifte da Bacia de Sergipe-Alagoas era tradi-

cionalmente considerada como tendo idade neo-

jurássica. A Formação Bananeiras é classicamen-

te correlacionada à Formação Aliança da seção

pré-rifte da Bacia do Recôncavo, Bahia. 

A Formação Aliança originalmente incluía três

membros: Afligidos, Boipeba e Capianga. Aguiar

e Mato (1990), com base em correlações regio-

nais, conteúdo paleontológico e geocronologia,

elevaram o Membro Afligidos à categoria de for-

mação, individualizando os membros Pedrão (Per-

miano) e Cazumba (Permiano a Triássico ?) e pro-

pondo uma sedimentação extensa e contínua

para a região. 

O resultado geocronológico agora obtido pa-

ra a Formação Bananeiras indica a possibilidade

da presença de uma seção de idade triássica

também na Bacia de Sergipe-Alagoas, amplian-

do a ocorrência de tal sedimentação na região

abrangida pela “Depressão Afro-Brasileira”

(Cesero et al. 1972 apud Cesero et al. 1997). A

amplitude espacial e a abrangência temporal da

bacia sedimentar implícitas neste conceito deve-

expanded abstract
The Rb-Sr whole rock isochron methodology has

been successfully applied when dealing with ages of

argillaceous fine grained sedimentary rocks. In many

cases, the age values obtained with the methodology

seem to be of some geological significance, yielding

ages in fair agreement with fossil content or with bios-

tratigraphic interpretations. Although these good

results, some doubts concerning the extension and

interpretation of the data are registered. These occur

as sedimentary rocks results from the mixing of detri-

tal fragments associated with diverse provenance.

Nevertheless, absolute ages of the depositional event

can be reasonably obtained if criteria such as sam-

pling, granulation, depositional environment and min-

eralogical composition of the samples are observed. In

order to improve the application of the methodology

to sedimentary rocks and searching for answers to

some doubts, the Bananeiras Formation, pre-rift sec-

tion of the Sergipe-Alagoas Basin was sampled. 

The evolution of the Sergipe-Alagoas Basin can be

roughly divided into four main phases: pre-rift, rift,

transitional and drift. The pre-rift phase is characterized

by the deposition of continental sections composed by

fluvial-deltaic-lacustrine deposits. These units were

deposited in a huge basin associated with the initial

tectonic process that led to the Gondwana breakup

and the evolution of the Brazilian continental margin.

This initial basin is recognized as the “Depressão Afro-

Brasileira” (Afro-Brazilian Depression).

The pre-rift section of the Sergipe-Alagoas Basin is

represented by the Perucaba Group which includes

Candeeiro, Bananeiras and Serraria formations.  In

the Bananeiras Formation we are mainly interested in

the pelitic unit of this phase; which is represented by

red shales with eventual silt fraction. This formation

has been considered as Upper Jurassic when correlat-

ed with the Aliança Formation of the Recôncavo

Basin. These pre-rift formations of the “Depressão

Afro-Brasileira” are considered as Upper Jurassic

based on the fossiliferous record (non-marine ostra-

cods, biozone RT-001, Dom João Stage). 

Twelve samples of the Bananeiras Formation were

collected according to the following criteria: close sam-

pling (centimeter), no visual presence of carbonates

and potassium minerals as micas and feldspars.  After

this initial procedure samples were analyzed using X-

ray diffraction and X-ray fluorescence techniques   and

afterwards they have been macroscopically described.

The results of these analyses appointed six samples to

autor principal

Diogo Rodrigues Andrade da Silva graduou-se em geologia pela Universi-
dade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul em 2004. Obteve o título de Mes-
tre em Estratigrafia pela Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul em
2006, defendendo tema de dissertação sobre a aplicação do método
radiométrico Rb-Sr em rochas pelíticas da Bacia do Paraná. Durante
seu mestrado, foi bolsista da Petrobras. Iniciou o doutorado em estra-
tigrafia na Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul, em 2006, como
bolsista do Conselho Nacional de Pesquisas Científicas (CNPq).

which the Rb-Sr whole-rock isochron methodology

was to be applied mainly due to the presence of

expansive clay minerals and to the Rb/Sr ratio.

The selected samples were prepared for 87Rb/86Sr

and 87Sr/86Sr isotopic ratios determination; which were

plotted in specific statistical software named Isoplot.

The result indicates an isochron of 227.1 ± 2.2 Ma

(Late Triassic); which was considered as the deposi-

tional age of the Bananeiras Formation. This unprece-

dented result has important implications to the paleo-

geographic schemes   previously   established,   as this

pre-rift unit has been traditionally considered as Upper

Jurassic.

The Aliança Formation (Recôncavo Basin) strati-

graphically correlated with the Bananeiras Formation

initially included three members: Afligidos, Boipeba and

Capianga. The Afligidos Member, based on regional

correlation, paleontological content and geochronology

was individualized as Afligidos Formation and Pedrão

(Permian) and Cazumba (Permian to Triassic?) Members

were defined indicating an extensive sedimentation

process in the region. The result obtained for the

Bananeiras Formation indicates the possibility of a

Triassic section also occurring in the Sergipe-Alagoas

Basin. This new concept for the region is strongly sug-

gestive of Triassic ages and the use of the Rb-Sr whole-

rock isochron methodology to sedimentary fine grained

rocks is the doctorate research project of the first

author.

                                  Manuscript Draft 

 

 

Manuscript Number: SAMES-D-11-00022 

 

Title: Determination of depositional age of Paleozoic and pre-rift supersequences of the Recôncavo 

Basin in northeastern Brazil by applying Rb Sr radiometric dating technique to sedimentary rocks

  

 

Article Type: Full Length Article 

 

Keywords: Recôncavo Basin 

Sedimentary rocks 

Pre-rift supersequence 

Paleozoic supersequence 

Rb-Sr method 

Depositional age 

  

 

 

Corresponding Author: Msc. Diogo Rodrigues Andrade da Silva,  

 

Corresponding Author's Institution: Serviço Geológico do Brasil/CPRM 

 

First Author: Diogo R Silva, Msc 

 

Order of Authors: Diogo R Silva, Msc; Mizusaki P Ana Maria, Doctor; Edison J Milani, Doctor; Paulo S 

Milhomem, Doctor; Pimentel Marcio, Doctor 

 

Abstract: The relative dating of sedimentary rocks can be done either from fossils found in them or by 

stratigraphic correlation. When they do not have a fossil content diagnostics, or when a correlation is 

neither possible nor conclusive, the task of estimating the depositional age of a particular rock is not 

possible. The method of Rb Sr isochrons in total rock has been successfully applied to fine-grained 

sedimentary rocks in order to determine the depositional age. Despite geologically significant results, 

in many cases, there still are about the extent and the interpretation of the data thus obtained. This is 

because sedimentary rocks result from the mixing of detrital fragments from different sources with 

different isotope systems, already containing an isotope record of the source rock. However, it is 

possible to obtain the absolute age of the depositional event provided some prerequisites with regard 

to sampling, granulometry, depositional environment and mineral composition of the samples, 

amongst others, are observed. Samples of argillite and siltstone of the Paleozoic and pre-rift sections of 

the Recôncavo Basin, stratigraphically positioned at the basal portion of the Afligidos (Cazumba 

Member), Aliança (Capianga Member) and Itaparica formations, were analyzed. The isochrons thus 

obtained yielded ages of 290 ± 21 Ma (Permian), 224 ± 32 Ma, and 226 ± 6 Ma (Neotriassic), 

respectively, which were interpreted as being the depositional ages. Results obtained for the units of 

the pre-rift section (Aliança and Itaparica formations) offer significant implications to the 

paleogeographic schemes established earlier for the Recôncavo Basin and other correlated basins, 

since these sedimentary units were traditionally considered as being of Neojurassic age.

ABSTRACT 20 

 21 

The relative dating of sedimentary rocks can be done either from fossils found in them or by 22 

stratigraphic correlation. When they do not have a fossil content diagnostics, or when a 23 

correlation is neither possible nor conclusive, the task of estimating the depositional age of a 24 

particular rock is not possible. The method of Rb-Sr isochrons in total rock has been 25 

successfully applied to fine-grained sedimentary rocks in order to determine the depositional 26 

age. Despite geologically significant results, in many cases, there still are about the extent and 27 

the interpretation of the data thus obtained. This is because sedimentary rocks result from the 28 

mixing of detrital fragments from different sources with different isotope systems, already 29 

containing an isotope record of the source rock. However, it is possible to obtain the absolute 30 

age of the depositional event provided some prerequisites with regard to sampling, 31 

granulometry, depositional environment and mineral composition of the samples, amongst 32 

others, are observed. Samples of argillite and siltstone of the Paleozoic and pre-rift sections of 33 

the Recôncavo Basin, stratigraphically positioned at the basal portion of the Afligidos 34 

(Cazumba Member), Aliança (Capianga Member) and Itaparica formations, were analyzed. The 35 

isochrons thus obtained yielded ages of 290 ± 21 Ma (Permian), 224 ± 32 Ma, and 226 ± 6 Ma 36 

(Neotriassic), respectively, which were interpreted as being the depositional ages. Results 37 

obtained for the units of the pre-rift section (Aliança and Itaparica formations) offer significant 38 

implications to the paleogeographic schemes established earlier for the Recôncavo Basin and 39 

other correlated basins, since these sedimentary units were traditionally considered as being of 40 

Neojurassic age.  41

1. Introduction 44 

 45 

The relative dating of sedimentary rocks can be done either from fossils found in them 46 

or by stratigraphic correlation. When they do not have a fossil content diagnostics, or when a 47 

correlation is neither possible nor conclusive, the task of estimating the depositional age of a 48 

particular rock is not possible. In such cases, the radiometric dating techniques usually applied 49 

to igneous and metamorphic rocks to obtain absolute ages have been tentatively used with the 50 

purpose of determining the depositional ages and/or the diagenetic phases of the sedimentary 51 

rocks (Cordani et al., 1978; Thomaz Filho & Lima, 1979; Silva et al., 2006a). 52 

Rb-Sr radiometric dating of sedimentary rocks is a technique which has achieved 53 

geologically significant results, provided some prerequisites are observed, such as: excellent 54 

stratigraphic control of the sampling, low silt/clay ratio, and mineralogy of the fine fraction of 55 

samples rich in expansive clay minerals (smectite, interstratified illite-smectite and degraded 56 

illite) (Whitney & Hurley, 1964; Byscae & Dasch, 1971; Cordani et al., 1978; Morton, 1985; 57 

Mizusaki, 1992). Although there still are some questions regarding the use of this technique 58 

with sedimentary rocks, many significant results have been obtained (Mizusaki et al., 1998; 59 

Silva et al., 2006b).  60 

The Brazilian continental margin is an example of passive continental margin, in which 61 

the tectono-sedimentary phases of pre-rift, rift, and drift are described. A classical pre-rift 62 

example is the basal section of the Recôncavo Basin, which does not include any elements to 63 

support a precise biostratigraphic dating of the sedimentary units due to the endogenous features 64 

of the non-marine ostracod micropaleontological content, associated with sparsely varied and 65 

low palynomorph content (Arai et al., 1989).  66 

A Paleozoic sequence is also found in this basin (Silva et al., 2007), with units 67 

deposited under arid paleoclimate and a context of intracratonic basin developed before the pre-68 

rift stage. The ages assigned to the Paleozoic are also subject of discussion due to their poor 69 

fossil records (Milani et al., 2007). 70 

Given the importance and significance of obtaining absolute ages of the Paleozoic and 71 

pre-rift sedimentary sections, which serve as a link to sections with international references, it 72 

seems to be interesting to follow this line of research.  73 

In this regard, we analyzed samples of fine-grained siliciclastic rocks from the 74 

Paleozoic and pre-rift sections of the Recôncavo Basin, a geologically well-known region, but 75 

with large gaps of knowledge about depositional ages. 76

2. Basal Section of the Recôncavo Basin 81 

 82 

The Recôncavo Basin is located in the northeastern region of Brazil and it spreads over 83 

an area of 11,500 km2. It is limited to the north and northwest by the Alto de Aporá, to the south 84 

by the Barra fault system, to the west by the Maragogipe Fault, and to the east by the Salvador 85 

fault system. 86 

The structural configuration of the basin is related to extensional efforts that resulted in 87 

the breakup of the Gondwana supercontinent during the Eocretaceous, bringing about the 88 

opening of the Atlantic Ocean and the development of the Brazilian continental margin.  89 

The tectono-sedimentary development of the Brazilian continental margin, from the 90 

Gondwana Mesozoic breakup (called Wealdenian Reactivation, Almeida, 1967) on, has been 91 

interpreted by different authors (e.g. Asmus & Porto, 1980; Chang et al., 1990).  92 

According to Silva et al. (2007), the sedimentary package of the Recôncavo Basin is 93 

formed of four supersequences: Paleozoic, pre-rift, rift, and post-rift. The sedimentary units of 94 

the Paleozoic and pre-rift supersequences, the basal portion of the basin, are part of the present 95 

study (Fig. 1). 96 

INSERT FIGURE 1 97 

In the Paleozoic supersequence, the studied unit is represented by the Cazumba Member 98 

of the Afligidos Formation. Having been deposited during an arid paleoclimate and an 99 

intracratonic basin context, the facies associations that characterize the Paleozoic units show a 100 

regressive trend, with transition from a shallow, marginal marine sedimentation to isolated 101 

evaporite basins, continental sabkha environments and, ultimately, lacustrine systems (Aguiar & 102 

Mato, 1990). In the Cazumba Member, red lacustrine pelites and mudstones prevail, with 103 

anhydrite nodules at the base of the section. The age of the Cazumba Member is subject of 104 

discussion due to its poor fossil record. According to Caixeta et al. (1994), the deposition of the 105 

Afligidos Formation is limited to the Permian.  106 

The pre-rift supersequence comprises deposits related to the initial stage of the crustal 107 

flexure. By pre-rift one understands the sedimentary package accumulated in a broad and 108 

shallow basin of flexural origin; the origin of this depression is tectonically associated with the 109 

large-scale extensional process, subsequently culminating in the rift phase and continental 110 

rifting. At the time of the pre-rift sedimentation, the normal faultings were still rare and 111 

contained not very significant debris. Cesero et al. (1972, apud Cesero et al., 1997) called this 112 

broad basin the Afro-Brazilian Depression, and sediments of continental source, corresponding 113 

to fluvial deposits locally reworked by the wind, and from very shallow lacustrine deposits, all 114 

with red bed features, were deposited in it. 115

According to the lithostratigraphy, the pre-rift section of the Recôncavo Basin 116 

corresponds to the Brotas Group and partially to the Santo Amaro Group. The Brotas Group 117 

includes the Aliança (Boipeba and Capianga members) and Sergi formations, while the Santo 118 

Amaro Group is composed of the Itaparica and Água Grande formations. 119 

According to Silva et al. (2007), the pre-rift sedimentation comprises there big fluvial-120 

aeolian cycles, represented from the basement to the top by the Boipeba Member and the Sergi 121 

and Água Grande formations. Lacustrine transgressions of regional nature separate these cycles 122 

and are expressed by a predominantly pelitic sedimentation, which characterizes the Capianga 123 

Member (Aliança Formation), and the Itaparica Formation, which are the units studied herein.  124 

Stratigraphically correlated to the Bananeiras Formation of the Sergipe-Alagoas Basin, 125 

the Aliança Formation is considered a Neojurassic unit, due to its non-marine ostracod content, 126 

which in this case corresponds to the RT-001 biozone, Dom João Stage of the Recôncavo Series 127 

(Viana et al., 1971). According to Silva et al. (2007), the Itaparica and Água Grande formations 128 

are of Eocretaceous (Eoberriasian) age, as indicated by micropaleontological analyses. 129 

The correlation of the biostratigraphic zoning of the Recôncavo Series with 130 

international reference schemes to determine the section's age is a widely discussed issue, and 131 

several questions remain unanswered (Regali & Viana, 1989; Arai et al., 1989). Particularly in 132 

the case of the pre-rift, Arai et al. (1989) postulate that “... there is no dating data which allow 133 

us to assign a Neojurassic age to the Dom João Stage...”. The same authors remind that 134 

equivalent units in the Gabon Basin were dated as Middle Jurassic by palynology (Wenger, 135 

1973, apud Arai et al., 1989). The fact is that the endogenous characteristics of the 136 

micropaleontological content of non-marine ostracods, upon which the biostratigraphic scheme 137 

of the Recôncavo Series is based, and combined with sparsely varied and sparsely abundant 138 

content in palynomorphs, do not lend themselves to a greater progress than that already 139 

achieved in terms of correlation with reference sections and age determination. It is crucial to 140 

try to date the rocks of this section in order to obtain absolute geochronological determinations. 141 

 142 

3. The Rb-Sr radiometric technique applied to sedimentary rocks 143 

 144 

The Rb-Sr radiometric technique is based on the radioactive decay of the 87Rb isotope, 145 

which is change into 87Sr. This radioactive decay takes place according to a decay constant l of 146 

known value, at a rate of 1.42 X 10-11.year-1, which corresponds to a half-life of 48.8 Ga. 147 

This method has been traditionally used for determining the absolute ages of igneous 148 

rocks, as they were formed under conditions of high temperature. In the case of magma 149 

crystallization, radiogenic 87Sr has considerable mobility and migrates between the mineral 150 

phases so long as the temperature remains above 350 °C. As a result, the phenomenon of Sr 151 

isotope standardization takes place, which is interrupted by the cooling of that particular rock. 152

Therefore, the Rb-Sr age will be related to this closing process of the system obtained in the 153 

rock crystallization event. 154 

In a sedimentary environment, characterized by lower temperatures and material from 155 

various sources, the Rb and Sr ion behavior varies. Rb is more easily adsorbed by clay minerals, 156 

whilst Sr tends to be released from the crystalline structure of minerals into the interstitial 157 

fluids. It is assumed that this characteristic favors the process of Sr isotope homogenization 158 

during sediment deposition in a particular basin, a condition required for Rb-Sr radiometric 159 

dating (Compston & Pidgeon, 1962; Faure, 1986; Mizusaki, 1992). 160 

If the assumption of Sr isotope homogenization in sediments during their deposition is 161 

valid, a successful radiometric dating by Rb-Sr technique in sedimentary rocks depends – as 162 

pointed out by Mizusaki (1992), Mizusaki et al. (1998) and Cordani et al. (2004) – of selecting 163 

samples with a high content of clay composed of expansive clay minerals such as smectite and 164 

interstratified illite-smectite sampled according to the recommendations of Thomaz Filho & 165 

Lima (1979). 166

4. Methodology 168 

 169 

4.1. Sampling  170 

The samples used in the present study were collected at the Paleozoic and pre-rift 171 

sections of the Recôncavo Basin, which are stratigraphically positioned at the basal portion of 172 

the Afligidos (Cazumba Member), Aliança (Capianga Member) and Itaparica formations (Fig. 173 

1)  174 

This section also includes the Sergi Formation and the Boipeba and Pedrão members of 175 

the Aliança and Afligidos formations, respectively. However, since these units are texturally 176 

formed of very fine-grained siltstones and sandstones, and in view of the chosen criteria, they 177 

were not deemed suitable for applying the Rb-Sr radiometric technique (Mizusaki, 1992; 178 

Cordani et al., 2004) 179 

Forty-three (43) samples were collected from outcrops along the BR-101 and BR-324 180 

highways, near the city of Salvador (Bahia, Brazil). The precise location of the sampling sites 181 

can be seen in Figure 2 and Table 1. At each point, 500 to 700 g of rocks were sampled in their 182 

natural state. The traditional sampling technique (Thomaz Filho & Lima, 1979) was used, 183 

whereby a minimum of four samples was collected from each outcrop, at a distance of 184 

approximately 1 m horizontally and 10-50 cm vertically. 185

4.2 Analytical procedures 192 

The samples were described macroscopically, with homogeneous portions of each 193 

sample being selected for analysis by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray fluorescence (XRF) and 194 

mass spectrometry techniques.  195 

For the X-ray diffraction analysis, we used the Siemens D5000 diffractometer of the 196 

Laboratory of X-ray Diffractometry of the Geosciences Institute of the Federal University of 197 

Grande do Sul (UFRGS), with KaCu radiation set at 40 kV and 30 mA of filament current and a 198 

2 to 28° (2q) range. 199 

 Sample preparation for XRD followed procedures described by Alves (1987), with the 200 

samples being first powdered with a pestle and an agate mortar. Approximately 5 g of the 201 

resulting powder were dispersed in 50 mL of distilled water and put to ultrasound, in the 202 

presence of a sodium pyrophosphate solution used as deflocculating agent. The <2 ?m fraction 203 

(FF <2 ?m) was separated from the resulting solution with a centrifuge. This fraction was 204 

placed on two slides, where clay minerals were directed by using the smear technique (Gibbs, 205 

1965). The prepared slides are dried under ambient conditions. 206 

 First, the slide dried under ambient conditions (standard slide) was analyzed. The 207 

second slide was soaked with ethylene glycol (CH2OHOH2OH) and forms the glycolated 208 

sample. After analyzing the glycolated slide in the diffractometer, it was calcined for 2 h in an 209 

oven at 500 °C in order to obtain the calcined slide. From the combined analysis of the 210 

diffractograms obtained with the standard, glycolated and calcined material, the clay minerals in 211 

the samples were identified.  212 

Sample analyses were performed in the Laboratory of X-ray Fluorescence of the 213 

Geosciences Institute of the Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS) using a Rigaku 214 

Model RIX 2000 device set at 40 kV, 20 mA. The samples were prepared in the form of 215 

compressed tablets obtained from 10 g of rock powder. The purpose of the analysis was to 216 

determine Rb and Sr mean values.  217 

With regard to mass spectrometry analysis, we chose to use only the <2 ?m-fraction 218 

(clay fraction separated according to procedures described previously) of the samples from the 219 

Aliança (Capianga Member) and Itaparica formations, since the coarse fraction of the samples 220 

contained a high level of detrital micaceous rock fragments, which could contribute with source 221 

area Sr. 222

Analyses by mass spectrometry to determine the isotope ratios were performed in the 223 

Laboratory of Isotope Geology of the Geosciences Institute of the Federal University of Rio 224 

Grande do Sul (UFRGS). 225 

First, the selected samples were dried in an oven under controlled, maximal temperature 226 

of 70 °C, thus avoiding damage to the structure of clay minerals, which would have impaired 227 

isotope analysis. Then, following procedures took place: 228 

· Semi-quantitative and quantitative measuring of Rb and Sr content by X-ray 229 

fluorescence 230 

· Total dissolution of the samples by chemical digestion and separation of the elements 231 

Rb and Sr through AG-50W-X8 cation-exchange resin columns from Bio Rad. 232 

· Analysis of isotope ratios by Micromass VG 354 Multi-collector spectrometer through 233 

isotope dilution technique. The elements, separated in the cation-exchange columns, 234 

were deposited on suitable filaments (Ta single filament for Rb and Sr) with 0.25N 235 

phosphoric acid (H3PO4) and analyzed in a "static mode". One-hundred ratios were 236 

measured with 1-V ion beam and external precision based on repeated measurements of 237 

an internal standard (20 ppm, 2 ?). All analyses were adjusted according to NBS-987 238 

internal and external standards (strontium carbonate), with a mean of 0.71028 ± 239 

0.00006. During chemical separation, Sr blanks were <150 pg, while Rb blanks were 240 

<750 pg (ideal values). 241 

· Preparation of isochron charts with isotope data obtained from the samples of 242 

sedimentary units from the basal section of the Recôncavo Basin by using Isoplot 243 

software (Ludwig, 2003). 244

5. Results 246 

 247 

5.1. Itaparica Formation 248 

The analyzed samples of the Itaparica Formation can be macroscopically characterized 249 

as reddish argillites, with significant presence of micaceous mineral fragments. Analyzes by X-250 

ray diffraction in the fine fraction (FF <2 ?m) allowed identifying the prevalence of the clay 251 

minerals kaolinite, smectite, illite with quartz traces, and interstratified illite-smectite. Results of 252 

the application of the Rb-Sr technique to the <2 ?g fraction are shown in Table 2. 253 

INSERT TABLE 2 254 

Rb values found in samples of the Itaparica Formation ranged from 54.44 to 94.02 ppm, 255 

and Sr values from 14.46 to 326.15 ppm. Values of the 87Sr/86Sr ratio ranged from 0.71736 to 256 

0.76715 and the 87Rb/86Sr ratio from 0.553 to 18.14. The isotope ratios obtained were plotted 257 

with the Isoplot statistical software (Ludwig, 2003), resulting in an isochron of 224 ± 32 Ma for 258 

the basal portion of the Itaparica Formation (Fig. 3). 259

5.2. Aliança Formation – Capianga Member 262 

The samples from the Capianga Member can be macroscopically characterized as 263 

reddish siltstones, with significant presence of micaceous mineral fragments identified as 264 

muscovite. Analyzes by X-ray diffraction in the fine fraction (FF <2 µm) allowed identifying 265 

the prevalence of the clay minerals illite and smectite, with traces of interstratified illite-266 

smectite. Results of the application of the Rb-Sr technique to the <2 µg fraction are shown in 267 

Table 2. 268 

Rb values in these samples ranged from 84.03 to 106.60 ppm. Sr ranged from 10.69 to 269 

56.98 ppm. Values of the 87Sr/86Sr ratio ranged from 0.73452 to 0.79995 and the 87Rb/86Sr ratio 270 

from 5.066 to 23.88. The isotope ratios obtained for the samples of the Capianga Member, 271 

Aliança Formation, were plotted with the Isoplot statistical software (Ludwig, 2003), resulting 272 

in an isochron of 226 ± 6 Ma (Fig. 4).  273

5.3. Afligidos Formation – Cazumba Member 276 

The samples of the Cazumba Member can be macroscopically characterized as reddish 277 

argillites. Analyzes by X-ray diffraction in the fine fraction (FF <2 ?m) allowed identifying the 278 

prevalence of illite, smectite and kaolinite. Results from the application of the Rb-Sr technique 279 

to total rock are shown in Table 2. 280 

Rb values ranged from 124.86 to 153.22 ppm, while those of Sr ranged from 51.60 to 281 

68.30 ppm. Values of the 87Sr/86Sr ratio ranged from 0.73756 to 0.74122 and of the 87Rb/86Sr 282 

ratio ranged from 6.223 to 7.133. The isotope ratios obtained for the samples of the Capianga 283 

Member, Aliança Formation, were plotted with the Isoplot statistical software (Ludwig, 2003), 284 

resulting in an isochron of 290 ± 21 Ma (Fig. 5).  285

6. Discussion  288 

 289 

With the final stages of the Brazilian/Pan-African Cycle (early Paleozoic) and 290 

cratonization of the South-American platform, we see the beginning of tectonics, which 291 

delineated the sites of future Paleozoic syneclises recognized in Gondwana. The great Brazilian 292 

Paleozoic basins or syneclises are well defined (e.g. the Solimões, Amazonas, Parnaíba and 293 

Paraná basins) and show extensive, predominantly continental, sedimentation. Paleozoic 294 

sedimentary basins are also recognized in the African portion of Gondwana (Figure 6). The area 295 

corresponding to the Paleozoic basins, particularly with regard to the Parnaíba Basin in 296

northeastern Brazil, has been subject of discussion, as it is assumed that they had different 297 

extensions and forms during the depositional cycles (Zalán et al., 1990).  298 

INSERT FIGURE 6  299 

 Small areas with sedimentary remnants have been observed there, which are considered 300 

remnants from earlier depositional cycles of varying ages. Several of these sections have a 301 

significant geographic expression as they were covered by younger sedimentary successions, 302 

which have preserved them. Milani et al. (2007) report the local presence of Paleozoic units 303 

under the Meso-Cenozoic sediments of the marginal basins and in their aborted branches. The 304 

Paleozoic section can be easily observed in the Recôncavo, Tucano, Jatobá and Sergipe-Alagoas 305 

basins. The Recôncavo, Tucano and Jatobá basins are examples of aborted intracontinental rift, 306 

having been formed together with the Sergipe-Alagoas Basin by the crustal stretching 307 

responsible for the breakup of the Gondwana supercontinent and the development of the 308 

Brazilian marginal basins. The basins are located in the so-called Afro-Brazilian Depression 309 

(Cesero et al., 1972, apud Cesero et al., 1997) as shown in Figure 7. By Afro-Brazilian 310 

Depression one understands this broad NW-SE intracontinental rift associated with crustal 311 

stretching, which resulted in the separation of South America from Africa during the formation 312 

of the South Atlantic Ocean and the Brazilian continental margin. It is considered that at the end 313 

of the Lower Cretaceous the western branch of the rift was aborted, allowing the preservation of 314 

this trench at stage prior to the total breakup of the crust and, therefore, not allowing the 315 

deposition of marine sediments inside its flume (Santos et al., 1990).  316 

INSERT FIGURE 7  317 

 The infill included a so-called pre-rift package (Fig. 1) constituted of shallow 318 

continental alluvial, aeolian and lacustrine sediments. These are the so-called Aliança, Sergi and 319 

Itaparica formations. 320 

Before this period, Paleozoic sedimentation has also been described in the area relative 321 

to the basins of the interior rift, which would form the future Afro-Brazilian Depression, 322 

associated with an extended stage of subsidence, which might have contributed to the 323 

development of an intracratonic-type basin. In the case of the Recôncavo Basin, it is the 324 

Afligidos Formation (with the Pedrão and Cazumba members). 325 

The Paleozoic sequence in this region has been widely discussed, but its recognition and 326 

extension is impaired due to lack of dating. Moreover, how much time elapsed between the 327 

conditions of Paleozoic sedimentation and the beginning of conditions that would give rise to 328 

the Afro-Brazilian Depression?  329 

Concerning the Recôncavo Basin, palynological data have assigned a Permian age to 330 

the Pedrão Member (Afligidos Formation), which correlates with the Ingá Member of the Santa 331 

Brígida Formation (Northern Tucano) and the Aracaré (Sergipe-Alagoas Basin) and Pedra de 332 

Fogo (Parnaíba Basin) formations (Fig. 8).  333

INSERT FIGURE 8 334 

 The age of the Cazumba Member is a point of discussion due to its poor fossil record. 335 

Equally based on palynological analyses, Aguiar & Mato (1990) admitted a potential extension 336 

of this unit into the Triassic. For these authors, its contact with the Boipeba Member (Aliança 337 

Formation) is inconsistent in most parts of the Recôncavo Basin, but considered transitional in 338 

the southwestern area of the basin, which would reinforce the question of interval's 339 

chronostratigraphic positioning. Caixeta et al. (1994) restrict the deposition of the Afligidos 340 

Formation to the Permian. 341 

The absolute age of 290 ± 21 Ma obtained for the Cazumba Member of the Afligidos 342 

Formation based on Rb-Sr radiometric dating confirms a Permian age for this interval. 343 

However, with regard to the pre-rift phase, assuming that the location of the future 344 

depression was a slightly depressed region (?), whose sedimentation conditions were 345 

continental, there is also much discussion about its relationship with the Paleozoic sequence and 346 

about when its development began. In that time interval, the conditions were lacustrine, and the 347 

few fossils found were of endemic ostracods, which do not allow a correlation with other 348 

regions of the Earth. Considering that the sedimentation in this period was predominantly 349 

continental and characterized by the presence of ostracods, it is not possible to make a 350 

correlation with intervals in other areas. Therefore, we decided to use a regional time division 351 

characterized by stages, with the big question being which time intervals to assign to these 352 

stages. 353 

Thus, the name Dom João Local Stage was adopted where it is represented by the 354 

Aliança and Sergi formations (pre-rift sequence) in the Recôncavo Basin. With regard to age, 355 

Viana et al. (1971) assumed in a simplistic way that the ostracods found in the Aliança 356 

Formation are indicative of Jurassic age. However, according to Arai et al. (1989), there is no 357 

dating element to attest a Neojurassic age for the Dom João Stage. 358 

In the present study, the application of the Rb-Sr radiometric technique obtained 359 

isochronic ages of 224 ± 32 Ma (Neotriassic) and 226 ± 6 Ma (Neotriassic) for the samples of 360 

the Itaparica e Aliança (Capianga Member) formations. These values are considered 361 

representative of the depositional age of these units, since it is assumed that the Sr isotope 362 

standardization process was penecontemporaneous with the sedimentation process, according to 363 

criteria pointed out by Mizusaki (1992), Mizusaki et al. (1998), and Cordani et al. (2004), 364 

mentioned earlier. 365 

The absence of significant diagenetic alterations in the original mineralogy validates the 366 

result obtained as depositional age. In addition, the reported uncertainty is compatible with the 367 

application of the Rb-Sr technique to sedimentary rocks, as discussed by Mizusaki (1992). In 368 

the case of the Itaparica Formation, despite the error of the isochronous age being greater than 369

However, the absolute ages of 224 ± 32 Ma and 226 ± 6 Ma (Neotriassic) now obtained 372 

for the first time raise important implications regarding the paleographic schemes established 373 

earlier. The pre-rift section of the Recôncavo Basin was traditionally considered of Neojurassic 374 

age (Silva et al., 2007).  375 

However, a similar age had already been obtained for the Bananeiras Formation (Silva 376 

et al., 2006b) from the Sergipe-Alagoas Basin. According to Figures 8 and 9, it is assumed that 377 

the Bananeiras Formation correlates with the Aliança Formation. 378 

INSERT FIGURE 9 379 

Therefore, the geochronological results obtained for the Itaparica Formation, the 380 

Capianga Member (Aliança Formation), and the Bananeiras Formation (Sergipe Basin) indicate 381 

that sedimentation in the broad sedimentary basin (?) that developed in northeastern Brazil, 382 

known as Afro-Brazilian Depression (Cesero et al., 1972, apud Cesero et al., 1997) began at a 383 

Neotriassic age, possibly continuing till the Jurassic. This finding extends to other sedimentary 384 

units of the Brazilian and African Basins, since continental sediments of the formations Sergi 385 

and Aliança (Recôncavo, Tucano and Camamu, and Almada basins), Serraria and Bananeiras 386 

(Sergipe-Alagoas Basin), Brejo Santo and Missão Velha (Araripe Basin) and their correlate 387 

formations M’Vone and N’Dombo (Gabon Basin) (Cesero & Ponte, 1972, apud Cesero & 388 

Ponte, 1997) (Fig. 10) were deposited in this broad basin. 389 

INSERT FIGURE 10 390 

 Another very important fact that should be highlighted is that the pre-rift sedimentation 391 

in the Afro-Brazilian Depression occurred in an intracratonic basin, as a combined system of 392 

alluvial fans and interior lakes, under stable tectonic conditions, with no influence from the 393 

Gondwana breakup processes. Milani (1987), when describing the evolutionary model of the 394 

Recôncavo and southern Tucano rifts, in northeastern Brazil, reports that there are no evidences 395 

of crustal arching previous to the rift phase of these basins. The pre-rift sedimentation geometry 396 

characterizes a slow and gradual subsidence process of that region, typical of passive rifting.  397 

 One could also assume a previous association with a broader area of the Parnaíba 398 

Paleozoic basin. In this context, one might think of an integrated scheme for the northeastern 399 

region (Fig. 11) associated with earlier and concurring stages to the Gondwana rifting. The 400 

events associated with this process would have operated differently inside this region. With 401 

regard to the Parnaíba Basin – whose remnants are seen in areas where the northeastern interior 402 

basins (e.g. the Araripe Basin) and the Jatobá Basin developed –, it is known that during the 403 

Silurian it spread beyond its eastern boundary (Ghignone, 1972; Caputo & Crowell, 1985). 404 

Couldn't the same have taken place during other geological intervals? Most likely yes. 405

 Milani & Thomaz Filho (2000) showed that the Atlantic rifting (at about 200 Ma) broke 407 

the connection of the Parnaíba syneclise with similar basins presently found in northwestern 408 

Africa.  409 

 In addition, this basin shows Permian sedimentation, represented by the Pedra de Fogo 410 

Formation (Dino et al., 2002). When taking this dating for the Pedra de Fogo Formation into 411 

account, the Motuca Formation (Fig. 8) would have extended until the end of the Eotriassic. The 412 

Sambaíba Formation, superimposed on the Motuca Formation and underlying the Mosquito 413 

basalts (approximately 200 Ma, Mizusaki et al., 2002) is classified by Lima & Leite (1978) as 414 

Medium-Upper Triassic. This deposition coincided with profound environmental and tectonic 415 

changes in the region of the Parnaíba Basin associated with an early opening of the North 416 

Atlantic (Vaz et al., 2007). Extensional events, remobilization of ancient faults, and magmatism 417 

in particular characterized this period in the geological evolution of the area (Almeida, 2004). 418 

Therefore, during the Neotriassic, there was substantial magmatism (flows and sills) which, in 419 

the case of the Parnaíba Basin, was called Mosquito Formation.  420 

 The datings of the Bananeiras and Itaparica formations and the Capianga Member of the 421 

Aliança Formation were classified in this interval, represented by magmatism in the Parnaíba 422 

Basin, indicating that there was continental sedimentation in the area of the future rift. This 423 

could indicate that basic magmatism would be reported during the Neotriassic in those portions 424 

most affected by the beginning of the North Atlantic rifting, with depocenters of the Parnaíba 425 

Basin migrating to distant areas. 426 

 427 

7. Conclusions 428 

 429 

The geochronological results obtained for the Aliança and Itaparica formations of the 430 

Recôncavo Basin reinforce the potential occurrence of a Triassic section in the region 431 

comprising the Afro-Brazilian Depression (Cesero et al., 1972, apud Cesero et al., 1997) while 432 

the age dated for the Afligidos Formation confirms the Paleozoic age previously measured for 433 

that unit.  434 

Data from the Aliança and Itaparica formations combined with results obtained by Silva 435 

et al. (2006b) raise important implications for the paleographic schemes established earlier, as 436 

these sedimentary units were traditionally considered being of Neojurassic age. 437 

The spatial extent and temporal reach of the sedimentary basins implicit in this notion 438 

should be reviewed in light of the determination of Triassic ages extensively distributed in 439 

northeastern Brazil and their correlates in northwest Africa. // in view of Triassic ages found 440 

widely spread over Brazil's northeastern region and its correlated regions in northwestern 441 

Africa. 442

7.3. ARTIGO III 

 

Título: 

Whole rock geochemistry and isotopic compositions of Sr and Nd in pre-rift 

samples of the Camamu Basin, northeastern Brazil 

 

Autores: 

Diogo Rodrigues Andrade da Silva 

Ana Maria Pimentel Mizusaki 

Edison José Milani

 Journal of South America Earth Sciences 





                             Elsevier Editorial System(tm) for Journal of South American Earth Sciences 

                                  Manuscript Draft 

 

 

Manuscript Number: SAMES-D-11-00032 

 

Title: Whole rock geochemistry and isotopic compositions of Sr and Nd in pre-rift samples of the 

Camamu Basin, northeastern Brazil  

 

Article Type: Full Length Article 

 

Keywords: pre-rift; sedimentary rocks; geochemistry; isotopes; provenance. 

 

Corresponding Author: Msc. Diogo Rodrigues Andrade da Silva, Msc 

 

Corresponding Author's Institution: Serviço Geológico do Brasil/CPRM 

 

First Author: Diogo Rodrigues Andrade da Silva, Msc 

 

Order of Authors: Diogo Rodrigues Andrade da Silva, Msc; Ana Maria P Mizusaki, Doctor; Edison J 

Milani, Doctor; Paulo S Milhomem, Doctor; Koji Kawashita, Doctor 

 

Abstract: Chemical compositions in whole rock, together with isotopic correlations of Sr and Nd in 

samples of sedimentary rocks, have been considered useful parameters to estimate not only their 

provenance but also to make inferences about the depositional environment and weathering 

processes. The sedimentary units of the basal portion of the northeastern basins of the Brazilian 

continental margin, particularly those of the pre-rift sequence, have become subject of interest for a 

study based on chemical and isotopic data, since they lack fossil content to establish their age. The 

chemical composition in total rock in terms of major and trace elements, and Sr and Nd isotopic 

compositions of five outcrops attributed to the pre-rift supersequence of the Camamu Basin was 

analyzed with the purpose of characterizing and obtaining further information that would allow a 

better correlation amongst the sites studied. By analyzing the chemical composition of the samples, it 

was inferred that the outcrops studied represented the same sedimentary unit and that they might be 

correlated to the Capianga Member of the Aliança Formation of the Recôncavo Basin. The chemical 

index of alteration (CIA) showed the presence of conditions associated with a humid 

tropical/subtropical climate. The use of Nd isotopes for provenance purposes indicated the 

Paleoproterozoic rocks of the Sao Francisco craton as source area. This shows that the combined 

chemical and isotopic analyses can be useful to characterize and correlate lithologically homogeneous 

sequences.

1. Introduction 45 

Chemical compositions in total rock, together with isotopic correlations of Sr and 46 

Nd in samples of sedimentary rocks, have been considered useful parameters to 47 

estimate not only their provenance but also to obtain inferences about the depositional 48

environment and weathering processes. The complexity of this system has been 49 

discussed by several authors (Roser, 2000; Taylor, 1985), and the results obtained are 50 

interesting especially to help characterize sections of complex stratigraphy. 51 

In this sense, due to wide gaps in knowledge about depositional ages and their 52 

complexity in terms of correlation and stratigraphic knowledge, the sedimentary units of 53 

the lower portion of the passive continental margin of the Brazilian Northeast have 54 

become subject of interest for a study based on chemical and isotopic data. This 55 

situation is in the most basal portion and corresponds to the Paleozoic and pre-rift 56 

supersequences of the Brazilian marginal basins. 57 

The units of these supersequences are usually homogeneous and (void) lack of 58 

diagnostic fossils, making difficult their identification and stratigraphic characterization. 59 

The chemical compositions in total rock in terms of major and trace elements, as well 60 

as the isotopic compositions of Sr and Nd of five outcrops attributed to the pre-rift 61 

supersequence of the Camamu Basin were analyzed. In this basin, it is hard to identify 62 

the units associated with the pre-rift, since they are formed of red pelites with incipient 63 

lamination and locally with the presence of carbonate nodules. The purpose of the 64 

present study was to characterize the outcrops and to obtain further data to allow a 65 

better correlation amongst them.  66 

 67 

2. Geologic context  68 

 69 

The Camamu Basin is located in the coastline of the Brazilian state of Bahia, 70 

between parallels 13° and 14° S, and it forms the southern extension of the 71 

Recôncavo-Tucano-Jatobá rift system (Fig. 1) With an area of about 13,000 km2 (of 72 

which emerged 2,000 km2), the Camamu Basin contains some accumulations of oil and 73 

gas accumulations on land and at sea, all considered to originate from Eocretaceous 74 

lacustrine source rocks of the Morro do Barro Formation (Gonçalves, 2000). 75 

INSERT FIGURE 1 76 

To the north, the border of the Camamu Basin with the Recôncavo and Jacuípe 77 

basins is marked by the Barra Fault, an important regional feature that crosses the 78 

basin from east to west. The Camamu and Jacuípe basins bound the Sao Francisco 79 

craton in its eastern portion. To the south, the border with the Almada Basin is only 80 

geographic, where a both structural and stratigraphic continuity between these basins 81 

is observed.  82 

The origin of the Camamu Basin, as well as of the remaining Meso-Cenozoic 83 

basins of the Brazilian continental margin, is correlated with the process of crustal 84 

stretching, which climaxed in the Gondwana breakup and the formation of the Atlantic 85

Ocean, following the model of the Brazilian continental margin (Ponte & Asmus, 1976; 86 

Asmus & Guazelli, 1981; Chang et al., 1992).  87 

The crystalline basement of the Camamu Basin is part of the Sao Francisco 88 

craton (Almeida, 1977). It is characterized by the geotectonic units called Jequié Block 89 

and Itabuna-Salvador-Curaçá Block (Barbosa & Sabaté, 2002, 2003). These units are 90 

potential source areas of the basin and they are formed by a set of Archean and 91 

Paleoproterozoic rocks.  92 

According to Caixeta et al., (2007), the sedimentary package of the Camamu 93 

Basin is formed of five supersequences: Paleozoic, pre-rift, rift, post-rift, and drift (Fig. 94 

2). 95 

INSERT FIGURE 2 96 

The tectono-sedimentary evolution of the Camamu Basin might be described as 97 

a succession of stages: (1) syneclyse, which precedes the beginning of the 98 

development of the continental margin and comprises continental and marine 99 

sediments of Permian age and which correspond, in lithostratigraphic terms, to the 100 

Afligidos Formation; (2) pre-rift, which comprises the fluvial-lacustrine sediments of 101 

Jurassic/Eocretaceous age of the Aliança, Sergi and Itaípe formations; (3) rift, 102 

represented by Eocretaceous lacustrine deposits of the Morro do Barro and Rio de 103 

Contas formations; (4) post-rift, which occurred in an environment of a sag-type basin, 104 

represented by Aptian transitional sediments of the Taipus-Mirim Formation; and (4) 105 

drift, which comprises the marine strata of Cretaceous to Tertiary age of the Algodões, 106 

Urucutuca, Rio Doce and Caravelas formations (Netto & Ragagnin, 1990; Gonçalves et 107 

al., 2000). 108 

 The pre-rift sequence – of Dom João – Rio da Serra (Neojurassic) age – was 109 

originally distributed over a great geographic extension, controlled by the Afro-Brazilian 110 

Depression (Estrela, 1972). Lithostratigraphically, the pre-rift section of the Camamu 111 

Basin corresponds to the Brotas Group and to the Santo Amaro Group. The Brotas 112 

Group includes the Aliança (Boipeba and Capianga members) and Sergi formations, 113 

while the Santo Amaro Group is composed of the Itaparica, Água Grande, and 114 

Candeias formations. 115 

According to Caixeta et al. (2007), the sedimentation of this sequence is 116 

characterized by sandy clastic sediments and shales deposited by interlaced rivers and 117 

with aeolian rework. Lacustrine transgressions of regional nature are expressed by a 118 

predominantly pelitic sedimentation, which characterizes the Capianga Member 119 

(Aliança Formation) and the Itaparica Formation, units of interest because of their 120 

lithology.  121

 The sedimentation of this stage is characteristically formed of oxidized, reddish 122 

sediments. In the Brazilian Northeast, the pre-rift sedimentation developed in the Afro-123 

Brazilian Depression, named by Cesero et al. (1972 apud Cesero et al., 1997) and 124 

which comprised the area currently occupied by the Sergipe-Alagoas, Camamu and 125 

Almada basins, in the south coast of the state of Bahia, including the Recôncavo, 126 

Tucano and Jatobá basins and their African counterparts. Stratigraphically, the units of 127 

the pre-rift sequence of the basins that developed in the Afro-Brazilian Depression are 128 

considered correlated and of Neojurassic age. 129

4. Methodology 131 

 132 

4.1. Samples analyzed and analytical procedures 133 

The samples used in the present study were collected at five different outcrops 134 

in the Camamu Basin (called Camamu 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5). These outcrops have been 135 

considered correlated and belonging to the same sedimentary unit, an assumption that 136 

will be investigated. The precise location of the sampling sites is shown in figure 3.  137 

INSERT FIGURE 3 138 

It must be highlighted that due to its stratigraphic location the Camamu 4 139 

outcrop (Fig. 4) was deemed to belong to the Aliança Formation, Capianga Member 140 

(pre-rift supersequence). As shown in figure 4, there is a local contact with sediments 141 

identified as belonging to the Sergi Formation (Figure 2). 142 

In the remaining outcrops, there is neither a contact nor a correlation with other 143 

units. In all outcrops, the rock is described as being a reddish pelite with incipient 144 

plane-parallel lamination, locally with carbonate nodules and associated with a fluvial-145 

lacustrine depositional environment. 146 

INSERT FIGURE 4 147 

 Efforts were made to collect pelites that visually showed a lesser degree of 148 

weathering alterations. However, the samples always showed evidence of intensive 149 

weathering processes and oxidations. Macroscopically, the samples collected at the 150 

five sampling sites were reddish argillites, locally with carbonate nodules always with 151 

presence of white mica fragments.  152 

 Around 500 to 700 g of rocks were collected from each sampling site. Care was 153 

taken not to contaminate the samples with fragments from other units; carbonate 154 

nodules were rejected. A minimum of four samples was collected at each outcrop, 155 

always maintaining a minimum distance of 1 m horizontally between each sampling 156 

site, according to the methodology by Thomaz Filho & Lima (1979). 157

After being collect in the field, the samples were pounded in an agate mortar 158 

and dried at <70 0C, to obtain the so-called whole rock (WR) sample. The TR samples 159 

were quartered in order to obtain fractions for X-ray diffractometry (XRD), X-ray 160

4.2. Chemical analysis 163 

 Major elements and all trace elements, except for Sr and Nd, were determined 164 

in 67 samples by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) technique by using a Rigaku Model RIX 165 

2000 device set at 50 kV and 50 mA, in the Laboratory of X-ray Fluorescence of the 166 

Geosciences Institute of the Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS). The 167 

samples were prepared as compressed tablets obtained from 10 g of rock powder. The 168 

chemical composition (major elements and trace elements) of the samples and their 169 

corresponding averages are shown in Tables 1 and 3. 170 

  171 

4.3. Isotopic analysis 172 

Sm-Nd isotopic analyses were performed in the Center of Geochronological 173 

Research of the University of Sao Paulo (CPGeo/USP). Rb-Sr analyses were 174 

performed in the Laboratory of Isotopic Geology of the Federal University of Rio 175 

Grande do Sul (LGI/UFRGS). Initially, the samples were dried under controlled 176 

temperature (up to 70 ºC) in order to avoid damage to the structure of the clay 177 

minerals. The semi-quantitative and quantitative determination of the Rb, Sr, Sm and 178 

Nd contents was achieved by X-ray fluorescence. About 0.1 to 0.2 g of powdered rock 179 

from each sample was dissolved with HNO3 and HF in Savilex vials, with the addition of 180 

isotopic tracers. Rb, Sr and REEs were separated in cationic exchange AG-50W-X8 181 

resin columns (200 to 400 mesh), and Sm was separated from Nd with anionic 182 

exchange LN-B50-A resin columns (100 to 200 ?m). Isotopic ratios were obtained 183 

using a VG SECTOR 54 mass spectrometer, with multi-collection system and 1.0 V ion 184 

beam, and Rb-Sr and Sm-Nd results were calibrated respectively against NBS-987 185 

(Strontium carbonate, mean 0.71026 ± 0.000014) and La Jolla (mean 0.511859 ± 186 

0.00001) standards. Blank values were lower than 150 pg for Sr and Sm and 750 pg 187 

for Rb and Nd. The isotopic ratios obtained are shown in Tables 2 and 4. 188

chemical and isotopic interpretations, with the purpose of identifying clay minerals 192 

present in the samples.  193

Analyses were performed in the Laboratory of X-ray Diffractometry of the 194 

Institute of Geosciences of the Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS). The 195 

equipment used was a Siemens diffractometer model Bruker aXS D500 equipped with 196

Sample preparation followed the procedures described by Alves (1987), with 198 

the slides undergoing three preparations, from which three spectra were obtained 199 

(standard, glycolated, and calcined); their combined interpretation was used to identify 200 

the clay minerals present in the samples, since their physical and chemical 201 

characteristics show different responses to the treatments.  202 

After these procedures, we performed the analyses, compared the 203 

diffractograms, and identified the clay minerals by standard procedure according to 204 

Brown & Brindley (1980) from the measure of the height of the major peaks. 205

5. Results 207 

 208 

5.1. Classification and composition of the rocks analyzed 209 

 Macroscopically and as described previously, the samples collected were 210 

reddish pelites, locally with carbonate nodules, always with white mica fragments.  211 

 The mineralogical composition of the clay fraction of the Camamu 2, 3, 4, and 5 212 

samples is constituted mainly of illite (I), smectite (S), interstratified illite-smectite (IS) 213 

as traces, and possibly quartz and K-feldspar. Kaolinite (K), illite (I), and quartz traces 214 

prevailed in the Camamu 1 samples.  215 

The rocks analyzed were classified according to the method proposed by 216 

Herron (1988), which, according to Roddaz et al. (2006), is appropriate for clastic clay 217 

rocks (Figure 5). 218

In the present proposition, most samples analyzed can be classified as Fe-220 

shales. These samples are characterized by high levels of Fe2O3 (8–12 %, Tab. 1). 221

The Rb-Sr radiometric method is traditionally used to measure the absolute 230 

ages in igneous rocks. In a sedimentary environment, characterized by lower 231 

temperatures, the behavior of Rb and Sr ions varies. Rb is more easily adsorbed by 232 

clay minerals, whilst Sr tends to be released from the crystalline structure of minerals 233 

into interstitial fluids. It is assumed that this feature favors the process of Sr isotope 234 

homogenization (i.e., isotope homogenization in sedimentary environment) during 235 

sediment deposition (Compston & Pidgeon, 1962; Faure, 1986), a condition required 236 

for Rb-Sr radiometric dating to be applied to sedimentary rocks. 237 

If the assumption of Sr isotope homogenization in sediments during their 238 

deposition is valid, a successful radiometric dating by Rb-Sr technique in sedimentary 239 

rocks depends – as pointed out by Mizusaki (1992) and Mizusaki et al. (1998) – on 240 

selecting samples with a high content of clay fraction formed primarily of expansive 241 

clay minerals such as smectite and interstratified illite-smectite, preferably sampled 242 

according to the recommendations of Thomaz Filho & Lima (1979).  243 

As shown in figure 6, no isochron chart could be plotted with all results from the 244 

isotopic ratios obtained for the five outcrops, due to their great dispersion. Therefore, a 245 

selection of points was performed as proposed by Thomaz Filho & Lima (1979). The 246 

points selected were plotted once more with the Isoplot statistical software (Ludwig, 247 

2003), resulting in an isochrone of 470 ± 17 Ma (Fig. 7). As shown in figure 7, the 248 

isotopic values used for obtaining the chart are represented mainly by samples from 249 

the Camamu 2, 3, and 4 outcrops.  250 

INSERT FIGURE 6 251 

INSERT FIGURE 7 252 

Possible reasons for the non-alignment of points of the Camamu 1 and 5 253 

samples are:  254 

· sediment provenance 255 

· high level of chemical alteration (Tab. 1) when compared to the remaining 256 

points 257 

· slightly different mineralogical composition, especially of the Camamu 1 258 

samples. XRD analyses of these samples did not show expansive clay 259 

minerals, which favor isotopic homogenization of Sr.  260 

In order to obtain preliminary information about the provenance of the units, we 261 

plotted a 87Sr/86Sr x 1/Sr chart, which is being used to indicate contributions from mixed 262 

sources. Figure 8 shows that the samples were usually located on the same straight 263 

line, indicating a common source. However, some samples of the Camamu 1 and 5 264 

outcrops did not fit in and drew a new straight line. This might indicate a contribution 265 

from a new source.  266

With regard to the measured age of 470 ± 17 Ma (Fig. 7), it is deemed too old 268 

as depositional age, due to the tectonic models proposed for the Camamu Basin 269 

(Caixeta et al., 2007). 270 

Therefore, one may hypothesize a "pseudo-isochrone", i.e., the points were 271 

aligned in the chart, but this result has no geochronological significance. Even for the 272 

samples collected at the different outcrops and positioned in individual isochrones, no 273 

actual value was obtained for the sedimentation age. The values obtained were always 274 

higher than expected, considering the current knowledge on this sedimentary section.  275 

 The results obtained can be associated with the abundant presence of detritic 276 

muscovite in the samples, even in the fine fraction. Mica contributed with Sr from the 277 

source rock; moreover, its structure does not allow the isotopic homogenization of Sr 278 

(Mizusaki, 1992), thus, contributing to obtain anomalous results. The results obtained 279 

might be further attributed to a possible contribution of K-feldspar, according to results 280 

of the X-ray diffraction analyses. 281 

Table 2 shows that 87Sr/86Sr values are high, evidencing contributions from 282 

fragments of old continental rocks, whose source will be verified next.  283

5.2. Characteristics of the total rock geochemistry  286 

The geochemical composition of sedimentary rocks is a complex function of 287 

various variables such as source material, weathering, transportation, physical sorting, 288 

and diagenesis (Middleton, 1960; Piper, 1974; Bhatia, 1983; McLennan, 1989; Cox & 289 

Lowe, 1995).Examples of using geochemical data from sediments for understanding 290 

sedimentary processes such as weathering, provenance, diagenesis, sorting, and 291 

recycling are increasing in the literature because of the sensitiveness of some key 292 

trace elements in identifying minor components that are not readily recognized 293 

petrographically (e.g., Hiscott,1984; Garver et al.,1996). 294 

The chemical composition of samples represents their primary mineralogy, 295 

which frequently underwent intense pre- and post-depositional chemical weathering 296 

processes (Nesbitt & Young, 1982). According to Button & Tyler (1979), cations such 297 

as Al, K, Mg, and Rb are always retained in weathering profiles, while cations of 298 

smaller ionic range, such as Na, Ca, and Sr, are rapidly leached and removed from the 299 

system. In addition, the amount of elements that is lost is proportional to the extent of 300 

the weathering. Table 1 shows the results of XRF analyses of samples from selected 301 

outcrops of the Camamu Basin. 302

 The charts were initially drawn based on the abundance of Al2O3 and taking into 303 

account that the samples come from predominantly clay rocks. The variance charts for 304 

the samples show some trends, as seen in figures 9 and 10.  305 

INSERT FIGURE 9 306 

INSERT FIGURE 10 307 

This suggests that the abundance of elements is controlled by the content of 308 

clay minerals. Pelites have higher K2O and are depleted of Na2O, revealing a higher 309 

proportion of clay minerals, especially illite and interstratified illite-smectite, according 310 

to XRD analyses. 311 

Although potassium is thought to be highly soluble in water, it tends to be 312 

conserved in some pelites because of the chemical stability of illite (Norrish & 313 

Pickering, 1983). Illite is relatively resistant to weathering and is potentially stable in 314 

soils except under extreme weathering conditions. 315 

CaO values are very low (Table 1), which might indicate a very quick alteration 316 

of plagioclase, according to criteria of Roser (2000). No traces of plagioclase were 317 

found in the fine fraction of the samples. 318 

TiO2 and Al2O3 are refractory oxides that are highly resistant to weathering in all 319 

but the most extreme environments, for example in long-lived weathering profiles in hot 320 

and humid conditions (Hill et al., 2000). This geochemical information contrasts with 321 

CaO, Na2O and Sr, which are relatively mobile and can be easily lost from pelites, Rb 322 

tends to be incorporated into clay minerals by adsorption and cation exchange during 323 

chemical weathering of fresh continental rock (Nesbitt et al., 1980). There is a strong 324 

negative correlation between Na2O and Rb which indicates that clay minerals in the 325 

clay mineral-rich fraction host the Rb. Elevated Rb and depleted CaO and Sr might 326 

suggest more intense weathering conditions in the hinterland but could alternatively be 327 

explained by a more felsic, Rb-rich source rock. Incompatible elements such as Rb, Y, 328 

Th and U are preferentially fractionated into melts during crystallization (e.g. Hall, 1996 329 

and references therein) and as a result these elements are enriched in felsic rather 330 

than mafic rocks.  331 

According to the proposition by Taylor & McLennan (1985), Zr occurs 332 

predominantly in the assembly of heavy minerals. The Camamu 1 samples show a 333 

significantly increased Zr. Due to the mineralogy (prevalence of kaolinite) and their 334 

chemical contents, these samples form the potentially most weathered set, which 335 

would explain the higher concentration of resistate minerals, such as zircon. 336 

With regard to minor elements, we found that barium (Ba) concentrations are, in 337 

average, always higher than those of strontium (Sr). These elements usually tend to 338

5.3. Chemical Index of Alteration (CIA) 358 

 The degree of weathering in source rocks can be obtained by various chemical 359 

indices, based on the composition in terms of major elements.  360 

 Herein, in order to measure the degree of weathering, we used the CIA index 361 

(Nesbitt & Young, 1982), which is based on the proposition that during chemical 362 

weathering the prevailing processes are feldspar degradation and clay minerals 363 

formation. The CIA (calculated as CIA= 100xAl2O3/Al2O3+CaO*+Na2O+K2O) of pelites 364 

of the Camamu Basin is given in table 1 and shows that a progressive weathering 365 

leads to loss of Na, Ca and K and increases Al values, as highlighted by Andersson et 366 

al. (2004). 367 

The CIA, therefore, could potentially be a useful index to characterize pelites in 368 

terms of the degree of weathering of the sediment source and in terms of variable 369 

source terrains for the Camamu samples. Worldwide average shale CIA values range 370 

between about 70 and 75; fresh granites give values of around 50 (Visser & Young, 371 

1990) while extreme weathering could produce values approaching 100. Camamu 372 

samples have CIA between 71.63 and 91.03 indicative of a high degradation. The 373 

average CIA of Camamu 1 samples is higher, suggesting stronger weathering 374

5.4. Correlations amongst Nd, provenance and geochemistry 390 

 The relatively immobile character of rare earth elements (REE) in most 391 

sedimentary processes (DePaolo, 1988; McLennan et al., 1990) allows the application 392 

of the Sm-Nd isotopic system to provenance research, even considering a possible 393 

slight modification of parameters during the sedimentary cycle (Awwiller & Mack, 1991; 394 

Zhao et al., 1992). According to McLennan et al. (1990), erosion, transport and 395 

deposition processes hardly affect the Sm-Nd system, and the measured ratios and 396 

calculated parameters in sedimentary rocks will faithfully reflect the characteristics of 397 

the source rock. Therefore, 143Nd/144Nd isotopic ratios, model age (TDM) and 398 

parameters such as ?Nd have been used as provenance tracers in recent sediments 399 

(McLennan et al., 1990), Paleozoic turbidites (Gleason et al., 1995), and 400 

Neoproterozoic siltstones and sandstones (Farmer et al., 2001). 401 

Relatively lower 143Nd/144Nd ratios (144Nd is the reference stable isotope) indicate 402 

crustal sources, while higher 143Nd/144Nd ratios suggest the input of mantle-derived 403 

juvenile material (DePaolo, 1988). The difficult visualization of the meaning of Nd ratios 404 

is overcome by the ?Nd parameter and by mantle extraction ages TDM. Positive or near-405 

zero ?Nd values, and TDM values near the crystallization age of an igneous suite, 406 

correspond to juvenile, mantle-derived components. On the other hand, negative 407 

results and significant difference between ages of extraction (TDM) and crystallization 408 

point to contamination by inherited, crustal material. 409

INSERT TABLE 4 415 

Sometimes, the explanation for this non-correlation is the fact that calculation of 416 

the TDM model age is based on the idea that the 
147Sm/144Nd ratio of the Earth's crust is 417 

more or less homogeneous (including granitic rocks and detritic sediments) of 418 

approximately 0.12 ± 0.02.  419 

Therefore, in the case of the studied samples, whose 147Sm/144Nd ratios did not 420 

fit this assumption, there might have been a fractionation between Sm and Nd. This 421 

means that the TDM model age, calculated based on this ratio, cannot be considered as 422 

the age of the Earth's crust formation. 423 

As shown in the chart ?Nd versus TDM age (Fig. 12), the results show that the 424 

samples originate from Paleoproterozoic rocks of the São Francisco craton. This 425 

interpretation is based on ?Nd values at the time of deposition of the sediments 426 

(approximately 150 Ma), since their values are around -25 and -15, a characteristic 427 

signature of Paleoproterozoic rocks of the São Francisco craton from the Itabuna-428 

Salvador-Curaçá orogen (Barbosa & Sabaté, 2002; 2003). 429

6. Conclusions 432 

The samples collected from outcrops of the Camamu Basin can be described 433 

as homogeneous, reddish, micaceous pelites showing dispersed carbonate nodules. 434 

They show good chemical and isotopic similarity in terms of total rock and, therefore, it 435 

is assumed that they are from the same sedimentary unit. Based on the geochemistry 436 

of total rock, this sedimentary unit might also be correlated with the Aliança Formation 437 

(Capianga Member), Recôncavo Basin pre-rift. 438 

When plotted in classification charts, most of these samples show to be Fe-439 

shales, since Fe2O3 values are high. 440 

The mineralogical composition based on analyses by X-ray diffractometry 441 

(XRD) shows illite, interstratified illite-smectite, smectite, kaolinite, and traces of K-442 

feldspar and quartz. Samples of the Camamu 1 outcrop were kaolinite-enriched, 443 

showing a strong weathering process. The CIA is increased and its results allow 444 

associating climatic conditions during the depositional age with a humid tropical or 445
